Definition: Given a comment, output 'Yes' if the comment is threatening, or 'No' if the comment is not threatening.

Positive Examples.input: Baloney.  You are going to see real action against Herr Trump and his white supremacist agenda.
Positive Examples.explanation: The comment suggests threat against Trump and his agendas and classified as threatening. Hence, it is a positive example
The comment suggests appreciation without any threats. It is classified as not threatening . Therefore, this is a positive example.

Negative Examples.input: Yet call out all Muslims for the acts of a few will get you pilloried. So why is it okay to smear an entire religion over these few idiots? Or is this because it's okay to bash Christian sects?
Negative Examples.explanation: The comment is genuine argument with no particular threat to Muslims or Christians, but classified as threatening. Therefore, this is a negative example.

Negative Examples.input: It's ridiculous that these guys are being called 'protesters'. Being armed is a threat of violence, which makes them terrorists
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment gives a claim and then tries to justify their claim. No threats have been made but its classified as threatening. Therefore, this is a negative example.

Releasing any invasive species into the wild is foolish.  Releasing an invasive predator is even worse.  Its prey have no natural defenses and are unaware of their habits.  This puts them at an extreme disadvantage in the food chain.  As mentioned before, cats don't just hunt to survive, they also hunt for sport.  I've had to deal with feral cats on a couple of occasions.  Like any wild animal, they are viscous, territorial and dangerous.  Feral cats aren't the same as your average house cat.  Yes, they are the same species but they're a completely different animal.  I would prefer not to have to kill them, but like Old Yeller, some times what must be done, must be done.

I challenge anyone to propose a reasonable alternative to eradication.  I know of none since these cats have no real natural habitat.  TNR is not a reasonable solution for any invasive species.  It devastates an entire ecosystem just to protect a handful of cats.  It should remain illegal.

Historically, Oregon legislators and State officials have had as much interest in quality higher education as they have had in Saturn. Their interest has been in how to get degrees to as many students as possible in as short a time as possible for as little expense as possible. Their euphemism for degrading education is "removing obstacles to graduation." I wouldn't count on them for holding anyone accountable for anything but spending less.

The UO, like many universities, has to cater to a customer base that includes out of state and international students in order for it to stay in business. How far this catering goes depends on "enrollment management" needs. EM is quite a complicated part of the forecasting business for hitting targets. These customers require marketing strategies and retention efforts against competition from other U's.

Given the pressures and limits, faculty at the UO generally do a courageous and effective job of preserving educational quality.
